title: Jaroslav Křička
text:
Jaroslav Křička (; 27 August 1882 in <a href="Kel%C4%8D">Kelč</a>, <a href="Moravia">Moravia</a> – 23 January 1969 in <a href="Prague">Prague</a>) was a <a href="Czech%20people">Czech</a> <a href="composer">composer</a>, <a href="Conducting">conductor</a>, and <a href="Music%20education">music teacher</a>. He was the brother of poet <a href="Petr%20K%C5%99i%C4%8Dka">Petr Křička</a>].
Life.
Jaroslav Křička was born into the family of the Kelč village cantor and headmaster František Křička (1848–1891) as the oldest of three siblings. His mother was Františka Křičková (1861-1936). His brother Petr Křička (1884–1949) later became a well-known poet, and his sister Pavla Křičková (1886–1972) became a writer. Their father enthusiastically supported the musical education of his children; Jaroslav received violin, piano, and voice lessons as a child.
He attended high school in <a href="Havl%C3%AD%C4%8Dk%C5%AFv%20Brod">Havlíčkův Brod</a> and graduated in 1900. As a high school student, he founded his own vocal quartet, <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a>, and student orchestra and began to compose. After graduating from high school, he moved to Prague and studied at the <a href="Prague%20Conservatory">Prague Conservatory</a> from 1902 to 1905. Under the tutelage of <a href="Josef%20Kli%C4%8Dka">Josef Klicka</a>, he studied <a href="Organ%20%28music%29">organ</a>, <a href="orchestration">orchestration</a>, and <a href="harmony">harmony</a>. He studied conducting with <a href="Karel%20Knittl">Karel Knittl</a>] and composition with Karel Stecker]. His musical role models were the famous Czech composers <a href="Anton%C3%ADn%20Dvo%C5%99%C3%A1k">Antonín Dvořák</a>, <a href="Bed%C5%99ich%20Smetana">Bedřich Smetana</a>, and <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Fibich">Zdeněk Fibich</a>, and later also the Czech <a href="Modernism%20%28music%29">modernists</a> <a href="V%C3%ADt%C4%9Bzslav%20Nov%C3%A1k">Vítězslav Novák</a> and <a href="Josef%20Suk%20%28composer%29">Josef Suk</a>.
After studying for a year in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> (1905–1906), he moved to <a href="Russia">Russia</a> for three years (1906–1909) and taught <a href="music%20theory">music theory</a>, harmony, and <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> at the Imperial Music School in <a href="Dnipro">Ekaterinoslav</a>. There he founded an orchestra with which he performed works by Antonín Dvořák and Bedřich Smetana. In Russia, he developed friendships with the composers <a href="Alexander%20Glazunov">Alexander Glazunov</a> and <a href="Sergei%20Taneyev">Sergei Tanejev</a>. Křička was inspired by Russian poetry and music, and the work of composers <a href="Mikhail%20Glinka">Mikhail Glinka</a> and <a href="Modest%20Mussorgsky">Modest Mussorgsky</a> particularly influenced his compositions. It was in Ekaterinoslav that he penned one of his most famous songs, "Albatross," from the cycle "Severní noci" "(Northern Nights)". Mussorgsky's song cycles for children also inspired him to compose his own children's songs.
Křička moved to Prague in 1909, and from 1911 to 1920 he directed the Prague choir Hlahol]. His tenure as director afforded him the opportunity to study numerous works by contemporary Czech composers such as <a href="Leo%C5%A1%20Jan%C3%A1%C4%8Dek">Leoš Janáček</a>, Vítězslav Novák, and <a href="Otakar%20Jeremi%C3%A1%C5%A1">Otakar Jeremiáš</a>, in addition to premiering Novák's cantata "Svatební košile (The Wedding Shirt)", Op.48. During this period, he also began his first major work: the opera "Hipolyta". From 1911 he championed his former teacher Karel Stecker at the Prague Conservatory, and after Stecker's death in 1919 he was appointed as a full professor of composition.
On October 14, 1918, he married Marie Krbová, a <a href="pianist">pianist</a> and singer in the Hlahol choir who studied under <a href="Josef%20Bohuslav%20Foerster">Josef Bohuslav Foerster</a>. Together with his student <a href="Jaroslav%20%C5%98%C3%ADdk%C3%BD">Jaroslav Řídký</a>, Křička conducted the choir of the <a href="Czech%20Philharmonic">Czech Philharmonic</a> from 1922 to 1930. During the critical years of World War II and the German occupation (1942–1945), he also served as <a href="Rector%20%28academia%29">rector</a> of the Conservatory.
During his many years of teaching at the Prague Conservatory, Jaroslav Křička trained numerous composers, including Jaroslav Řídký, Karel Hába, <a href="Emil%20Hlobil">Emil Hlobil</a>, Karel Janeček, <a href="V%C3%A1clav%20Trojan">Václav Trojan</a>, <a href="J%C3%A1n%20Cikker">Ján Cikker</a>, <a href="Jan%20Kapr">Jan Kapr</a> and <a href="Jarmil%20Burghauser">Jarmil Burghauser</a>. He spent the last years of his life in the peaceful foothills of the Bohemian forest, where he dedicated himself to his composing in the village of Červené Dvorce near <a href="Su%C5%A1ice">Sušice</a>. He is buried in the Vyšehrad cemetery in Prague.
Honors.
In 1936, Jaroslav Křička won a bronze medal <a href="Art%20competitions%20at%20the%201936%20Summer%20Olympics">in the art competitions of the Olympic Games</a> for his "Horácká suita (<a href="Hor%C3%A1cko">Horácko</a> Suite" a.k.a. "Mountain Suite)", Op. 63.
He was elected a member of the <a href="Czech%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Czech Academy of Sciences and Arts</a> in 1921, and in 1957 he received the esteemed title of Honored Artist (Zasloužilý umělec). The Křička Brothers Museum is located in his hometown of Kelč.
Works.
Jaroslav Křička's work encompasses almost all musical genres, in his words, “from <a href="Passion%20%28music%29">passions</a> to <a href="operetta">operetta</a>,” with a distinct emphasis on <a href="Vocal%20music">vocal</a> compositions. In addition to <a href="song%20cycle">song cycle</a>s and <a href="cantata">cantata</a>s, he also composed <a href="opera">opera</a>s, operettas, <a href="incidental%20music">incidental music</a>, <a href="Symphony">symphonies</a>, string quartets, and chamber music works. His compositions for children were significant and unique for his time; he wrote numerous children's song cycles and the first Czech children's opera, "Ogaři" (1918). At the end of the silent film era, Křička began composing <a href="film%20score">film score</a>s; in 1929, he wrote the music for the historical film "Svatý Václav", which commemorated one thousand years since the death of the Bohemian ruler <a href="Wenceslaus%20I%2C%20Duke%20of%20Bohemia">Wenceslaus I</a>. He began composing operettas after 1945.
In addition to his musical compositions, Křička wrote many treatises on music and published regularly in the music periodicals "Hudební revue" and "Hudební rozhledy".
